standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multi-step word problems with whole numbers

question.content: The art club raised $\$248$ through fundraisers.  Then they spent $\$206$ to set up an art show.  They raised another  $\$316$ at the art show.  **How much money did the art club have after the show?**   $\$$

hints.content: The club started with $\$248$ and then spent $\$206$.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{248}-\blueE{206}=\maroonD{42}$  The club had $\$\maroonD{42}$ left after they spent for the art show.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 248 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 206 and the other has no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled money raised through fundraisers. A curved bracket below the part labeled 206 is labeled money spent. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled money left.

hints.content: Then, they raised another $\$316$ at the show.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{42}+\goldE{316}=\greenE{358}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 42 and the other labeled 316. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled money after the show. A curved bracket below the part labeled 42 is labeled money left. A curved bracket below the part labeled 316 is labeled money from the show.

hints.content: The club had $\$\greenE{358}$ after the show.

question.content: After collecting eggs from his chickens, Dale puts the eggs into cartons to sell. Dale fills $15$ cartons and has $7$ eggs left over. Each carton holds $12$ eggs.  **How many eggs did Dale collect?**   eggs

hints.content: We can multiply to find the total number of eggs in all $15$ cartons.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{12} \times 15 = \purpleD{180}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 15 equal parts, each labeled 12. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total eggs in cartons. A curved bracket below 1 of the 15 parts of the second tape is labeled eggs per carton.

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of eggs, including the $\greenE{7}$ that were left over.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{180} +\greenE{7} = \redE{187}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 180 and the other labeled 7. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total eggs. A curved bracket below the part labeled 180 is labeled total eggs in cartons. A curved bracket below the part labeled 7 is labeled eggs left over.

hints.content: Dale collected $\redE{187}$ eggs.

question.content: A class sold tickets to their school play. Each of the $23$ students in the class sold $4$ tickets. The cost of each ticket was $\$7$.   **How much money did the class earn by selling tickets to the play?**  $\$$

hints.content: $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{number of students}} \times \maroonD{\text{tickets per student}} &= \greenE{\text{number of tickets}}\\ \blueE{23} \times \maroonD{4} &= \greenE{92} \end{align}$  The class sold $\greenE{92}$ tickets.
$\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of tickets}} \times \purpleD{\text{dollars per ticket}} &= \goldE{\text{total dollars}}\\ \green{92} \times \purpleD{7} &= \goldE{644} \end{align}$
The class raised $\$\goldE{644}$ by selling tickets to the play.

question.content: Abit is planning a birthday party for his granddad. He bought a cake for $\$18$. He also wants to buy some balloons, which are $\$4$ each. Abit has $\$35$ to spend all together.  **How much money will Abit have left after he buys the cake and as many balloons as possible?**   $\$$

hints.content: We can subtract to find out how much money Abit will have left after he buys the cake.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{35}-\greenE{18} = \purpleD{17}$  Abit has up to $\purpleD{17}$ dollars left for balloons.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 35 and a second tape divided into 2 unequal parts, one labeled 18 and the other with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled money for party. A curved bracket below the part labeled 18 is labeled money for cake. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled money not for cake.

hints.content: Each balloon costs $\$4$. We can divide the amount of money Abit has left after buying the cake by $4$ to find out how many balloons he can buy.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{17}\div\maroonD{4} = \goldE{4}\text{ R } \blueE{1}$  Abit can buy $\goldE{4}$ balloons and will have $\blueE{1}$ dollar left.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 17 and a second tape with 5 parts, 4 equal in length and each labeled 4 and 1 unequal in length and with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled money not for cake. A curved bracket below the 4 equal parts of the second tape is labeled 4 dollars each for question mark balloons. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled money left over.

hints.content: Abit will have $\$ \blueE{1}$ left.

question.content: A PE class has $48$ students. One group of $24$ students chooses to play volleyball. The teacher then divides the remaining students into as many groups of $5$ as possible to shoot baskets.   After that, the remaining students (not on a volleyball or basketball team) climb the rock wall.  **How many students climb the rock wall?**   students

hints.content: We can subtract to find the total number of students who do not want to play volleyball.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{48}-\greenE{24}=\purpleD{24}$  There are $\purpleD{24}$ students who do not want to play volleyball.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape is labeled 48, the bottom tape is divided into 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 24 and the other part not labeled. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled students in class. A curved bracket below the part labeled 24 is labeled students playing volleyball. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled students not playing volleyball.

hints.content: We can divide to put those students into groups of $5$.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{24}\div\maroonD{5}= \goldE{4} \text{ R } \blueE{4}$  There will be $\goldE{4}$ groups with $\maroonD{5}$ students and $\blueE{4}$ students still remaining to climb the rock wall.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 24 and a second tape divided into 5 parts. Four of the parts are equal and labeled 5. The fifth part has no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled students not playing volleyball. A curved bracket below the parts labeled 5 is labeled question mark groups of 5 students playing basketball. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled students on rock wall.

hints.content: $\blueE{4}$ students will climb the rock wall.

question.content: Sanji scored $125$ points in the first round of a video game and $263$ points in the second round. His total score after the third round was $557$ points.  **How many more points did Sanji score in the third round of the video game than in the first round?**    points

hints.content: We can add to find Sanji's total points for the first two rounds.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{125}+\goldE{263}=\greenE{388}$  Sanji had $388$ points from the first two rounds.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first with no label and a second with 2 unequal parts, one labeled 125 and the other labeled 263. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total points after 2 rounds. A curved bracket below the part labeled 125 is labeled points from round 1. A curved bracket below the part labeled 263 is labeled points from round 2.

hints.content: Then, we can subtract to find out how many points Sanji scored in the third round.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{557}-\greenE{388}=\purpleD{169}$  Sanji scored $\purpleD{169}$ points in the third round.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 557 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one labeled 388 and the other with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total points after 3 rounds. A curved bracket below the part labeled 388 is labeled points from first 2 rounds. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled points from round 3.

hints.content: We can subtract to find how many more points Sanji scored in the third round than in the first round.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{169}-\maroonD{125}=\tealE{44}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 169 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one labeled 125 and the other with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled points from round 3. A curved bracket below the part labeled 125 is labeled points from round 1. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled more points.

hints.content: Sanji scored $\tealE{44}$ more points in the third round than in the first round.

question.content: Erin had $55$ pebbles that she collected from hikes. She took out her favorite $7$ pebbles and then equally divided the other pebbles among her $3$ sisters. Erin's youngest sister, Su, already had $15$ pebbles.  **How many pebbles does Su have now?**   pebbles

hints.content: We can subtract to find the number of pebbles Erin gave away.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{55}-\maroonD{7} = \tealE{48}$  Erin gave away $\tealE{48}$ pebbles.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with labeled 55 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 7 and the other with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Erin’s pebbles. A curved bracket below the part labeled 7 is labeled pebbles Erin kept. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled pebbles Erin gave her sisters.

hints.content: She divided the pebbles she gave away equally among her $3$ sisters.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\tealE{48} \div 3 = \goldE{16}$  Erin gave each sister, including Su, $\goldE{16}$ pebbles.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with labeled 48 and a second tape with 3 equal parts without labels. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total pebbles Erin gave to get sisters. A curved bracket below the 1 of the 3 parts with no label is labeled pebbles Erin gave each sister.

hints.content: Su already had $\blueE{15}$ pebbles. We can add to find her total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{16} + \blueE{15} = \redE{31}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 16 and the other labeled 15. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Su’s total pebbles. A curved bracket below the part labeled 16 is labeled pebbles Erin gave to Su. A curved bracket below the part labeled 15 is labeled pebbles Su already had.

hints.content: Su has $\redE{31}$ pebbles now.

question.content: An ice cream shop is testing some new flavors of ice cream. They invent $25$ new flavors for customers to try, and throw out the $13$ least popular flavors.  The shop makes $80$ cartons of each of the remaining flavors. It takes $2$ cartons to get one liter $(\text{L})$ of ice cream.  **How much total ice cream is in the cartons?**    $\text{L}$

hints.content: We can subtract to find out how many new flavors of ice cream the shop made.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{25}-\goldE{13}=\blueE{12}$  The shop had $\blueE{12}$ remaining new flavors.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 25 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 13 and the other part with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled new flavors. A curved bracket below the part labeled 13 is labeled flavors thrown out. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled flavors remaining.

hints.content: They made $\maroonD{80}$ cartons per remaining flavor.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(flavors remaining)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(cartons per flavor)}} &= \greenE{\text{number of cartons}}\\\\ \blueE{12}\times \maroonD{80} &=  \greenE{960} \end{align}$  They made $\greenE{960}$ cartons of ice cream.

It takes $\purpleD{2}$ cartons to make $1\,\text{L}$ of ice cream.  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{(number of cartons)}} \div \purpleD{2} &= \redE{\text{number of liters}} \\\\ \greenE{960} \div \purpleD{2} &= \redE{480} \end{align}$
There were $\redE{480}\,\text{L}$ of ice cream in the cartons.

question.content: A farmer had $88$ melons growing in her garden. In June, the farmer had picked $14$ melons. In July, a thunderstorm knocked a branch from a tree and crushed half the melons that remained in the garden. Then the farmer picked the rest.  **How many melons did the farmer pick in June and July combined?**   melons

hints.content: We can subtract to find the number of melons that were left in the garden in June.    [[☃ image 1]]   $\purpleD{88}-\goldE{14}=\blueE{74}$  There were $\blueE{74}$ melons left in the garden at the end of June.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length, the top tape labeled 88 and the bottom tape divided into 2 unequal parts, the first part shorter and labeled 14 and the second part longer and with no label. A curved bracket above the top tape is labeled total melons. A curved bracket below the part labeled 14 is labeled melons picked in June. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled melons remaining.

hints.content: The branch crushed half the melons that remained in the garden, and the farmer picked the remaining half. So we can divide to find out how many melons the branch crushed and how many were picked.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{74} \div 2= \maroonD{37}$  The branch crushed $\maroonD{37}$ melons, so the farmer picked the remaining $\maroonD{37}$ melons.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes, of equal length, the top tape labeled 74 and the bottom tape divided into two equal parts each with no label. A curved bracket above the top tape is labeled melons in garden in July. A curved bracket below the first part of the bottom tape is labeled crushed melons. A curved bracket below the second part of the bottom tape is labeled melons picked in July.

hints.content: To find the total amount of melons the farmer picked in June and July, we can add the total amount of melons picked in each month.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{14}+\maroonD{37} = \greenE{51}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length, the top tape has no label and the bottom tape is divided into 2 unequal parts, the first part shorter and labeled 14 and the second part labeled 37. A curved bracket above the top tape is labeled total melons picked. A curved bracket below the part labeled 14 is labeled melons picked in June. A curved bracket below the part labeled 37 is labeled melons picked in July.

hints.content: The farmer picked $\greenE{51}$ melons in all.

question.content: Peter scored $15$ goals during his second soccer season as a forward. He scored $6$ fewer goals during his first season. The team as a whole scored $4$ times as many goals as Peter during the two seasons.  **How many goals did the team score during the two seasons?**   goals

hints.content: Peter scored $6$ fewer goals in the first season than in the second. We can subtract to find Peter's number of goals in the first season.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{15}-\maroonD{6}=\greenE{9}$  Peter scored $\greenE{9}$ goals in the first season.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 15 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 6 and the other part with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Peter’s goals the second season. A curved bracket below the part labeled 6 is labeled difference in goals. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled Peter’s goals the first season.

hints.content: We can add to find how many total goals Peter scored.    [[☃ image 1]]   $\greenE{9}+\purpleD{15}= \blueE{24}$  Peter scored $\blueE{24}$ goals during both seasons.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 9 and the other part labeled 15. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Peter’s total goals. A curved bracket below the part labeled 9 is labeled Peter’s goals the first season. A curved bracket below the part labeled 15 is labeled Peter’s goals the second season.

hints.content: The team as a whole scored $4$ times as many goals as Peter. We can multiply to find the number of goals the whole team scored.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{24} \times 4 = \redE{96}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 4 equal parts, each labeled 24. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled team’s total goals. A curved bracket below one of the parts labeled 24 is labeled Peter’s total goals.

hints.content: The team scored $\redE{96}$ goals during the two seasons.

question.content: Abigail buys two cartons of strawberries. One carton has $19$ berries and the other carton has $26$ berries. She wants to divide the berries into bags so there are exactly $6$ berries in each bag.  **How many bags will have $6$ berries?**   bags

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of berries in both cartons.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{19}+\maroonD{26} = \purpleD{45}$  There were $\purpleD{45}$ total berries

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 19 and the other labeled 26. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total strawberries. A curved bracket below the part labeled 19 is labeled strawberries in first carton. A curved bracket below the part labeled 26 is labeled strawberries in second carton.

hints.content: Abigail wants to divide the berries into groups of $6$. We can divide by $6$ to see how many bags she will need for all the berries.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{45}\div \greenE{6} = \redE{7} \text{ R } \goldE{3}$  $\redE{7}$ bags will have $\greenE{6}$ berries and $1$ bag will have $\goldE{3}$ berries.  We only need the number of full bags of $6$ berries.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 45 and a second tape with 8 parts, 7 parts equal in length and labeled 6 and 1 part unequal in length and with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total strawberries. A curved bracket below the 7 equal parts is labeled question mark bags of 6 strawberries. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled extra strawberries.

hints.content: $\redE{7}$ bags will have $6$ berries.

question.content: A group of $4$ friends is playing cards. The deck has $70$ cards. To start the game, the dealer makes a pile of $15$ cards  in the center. Then she deals the remaining cards one at a time to each player until all the cards are gone.    **What is the greatest number of cards any player will have after all the cards are dealt?**   cards

hints.content: We can subtract to find out how many cards will be dealt to the players.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{70}-\blueE{15}=\maroonD{55}$  There are $\maroonD{55}$ cards to deal.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 70 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 15 and the other part with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled all cards in deck. A curved bracket below the part labeled 15 is labeled cards in pile. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled cards to deal.

hints.content: Next, we can divide the number of cards to deal by the number of players.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{55}\div \greenD{4} = \tealE{13} \text{ R } \goldE{3}$  The $\goldE{3}$ extra cards will also go to players.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first labeled 55 and the second divided into 5 parts with no labels, 4 parts equal in length and 1 part not equal. A curved bracket above the top tape is labeled cards to deal. A curved bracket below 1 of the 4 equal parts with no labels is labeled least cards per player. A curved bracket below the unequal part is labeled extra cards.

hints.content: The *least* number of cards per player is $\tealE{13}$ cards, but $\goldE{3}$ players get an extra card. So $\goldE{3}$ players get $\redE{14}$ cards each.
The *greatest* number of cards any player will have after all the cards are dealt is $\redE{14}$.

question.content: Jordan's mom bought $7$ packs of juice boxes for the team to drink after practice. Each pack had $8$ boxes of juice. After the team drank as much juice as they wanted, there were $29$ boxes of juice remaining. The team only opened each pack after they drank all the boxes from the pack before.  **How many packs of juice  did the team open?**   packs

hints.content: We can multiply to find the number of boxes of juice Jordan's mom bought in $7$ packs.    [[☃ image 1]]  $7\times \blueE{8}=\redE{56}$  Jordan's mom bought $\redE{56}$ juice boxes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 7 equal parts, each labeled 8. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total juices. A curved bracket below one of the parts labeled 8 is labeled boxes per pack.

hints.content: If we subtract the $29$ boxes of juice that were left from the total, we will know how many boxes of juice the team drank.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{56}-\greenE{29} = \purpleD{27}$  The team drank $\purpleD{27}$ boxes of juice.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 56 and a second tape divided into 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 29 and the other with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total boxes. A curved bracket below the part labeled 29 is labeled boxes left. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled boxes the team drank.

hints.content: We can divide the boxes they drank by $8$ to see how many packs the team opened.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{27} \div \blueE{8} = \goldE{3} \text{ R }\maroonD{3}$  The team drank $\goldE{3}$ full packs and $1$ partial pack.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 27 and a second tape divided into 4 parts, three parts are equal and labeled 8 and the fourth part has no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled boxes the team drank. A curved bracket below the three parts labeled 8 is labeled question packs with 8 boxes each. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled boxes from partial pack.

hints.content: The team opened $4$ packs of juice.

question.content: A squirrel family collected $172$ nuts to store for the winter. They spread the nuts out evenly among their $6$ favorite spots. The squirrels ate the last few nuts that didn't divide evenly. Sadly, a crow stole half the nuts from one of the spots.  **How many nuts did the crow steal?**   nuts

hints.content: We can divide to find out how many nuts were in each of the $6$ spots.    [[☃ image 1]]   $\purpleD{172}\div 6=\maroonD{28}\text{ R }\blueE{4}$  The family ate the nuts left over, so there were $\maroonD{28}$ nuts per spot.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 172 and a second tape divided into 7 parts without labels, 6 parts equal and 1 part not equal. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total nuts. A curved bracket below one the equal parts is labeled nuts per spot. A curved bracket below the unequal part is labeled nuts the squirrels ate.

hints.content: The crow stole half the nuts from one spot.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{28} \div 2 = \greenE{14}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 28 and a second tape divided into 2 equal parts with no labels. A curved bracket over the first tape is labeled nuts per spot. A curved bracket under one of the parts with no label is labeled stolen nuts.

hints.content: The crow stole $\greenE{14}$ nuts.

question.content: The drama group has $90$ minutes to practice two scenes. They want to practice the pirate scene $4$ times, and each time takes $13$ minutes. The mermaid scene takes $7$ minutes.   **How many full times can the group practice the mermaid scene?**   times

hints.content: We can multiply to find how long it takes to practice the pirate scene $4$ times.    [[☃ image 1]]  $4\times \maroonD{13}=\blueE{52}$  The group will practice the pirate scene for $\blueE{52}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape with no label and a second tape with 4 equal parts each labeled 13. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total minutes practicing pirate scene. A curved bracket below one of the parts labeled 13 is labeled minutes per pirate scene practice.

hints.content: If we subtract the $\blueE{52}$ minutes from the total, we will know how much time is left.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{90}-\blueE{52} = \purpleD{38}$  There will be $\purpleD{38}$ minutes left to practice the mermaid scene.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 90 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 52 and the other part with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total minutes. A curved bracket below the part labeled 52 is labeled minutes practicing pirate scene. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled minutes for practicing mermaid scene.

hints.content: We can divide to see how many times the group can practice the mermaid scene.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{38} \div \greenE{7} = \tealE{5} \text{ R }\goldE{3}$  The group has time for $\tealE{5}$ full times with $\goldE{3}$ minutes left over.  That is not enough time to practice the scene one more time.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 38 and a second tape divided into 6 parts, 5 parts equal in length and each labeled 7 and 1 part unequal in length with no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled minutes for practicing mermaid scene. A curved bracket below the 5 equal parts is labeled question mark practices for 7 minutes each. A curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled minutes left over.

hints.content: The group can practice the mermaid scene $\tealE{5}$ full times.
